001package squidpony.squidgrid.mapping;
002
003
004import squidpony.ArrayTools;
005import squidpony.squidgrid.Direction;
006import squidpony.squidmath.Coord;
007import squidpony.squidmath.GWTRNG;
008import squidpony.squidmath.IRNG;
009import squidpony.squidmath.OrderedSet;
010
011import java.util.ArrayList;
012
013/**
014 * A maze generator that can be configured using a {@link ChoosingMethod}, which can be customized for the app.
015 * Based in part on code from <a href="http://weblog.jamisbuck.org/2011/1/27/maze-generation-growing-tree-algorithm">Jamis Buck's blog</a>.
016 * @author Eben Howard - http://squidpony.com - howard@squidpony.com
017 */
018public class GrowingTreeMazeGenerator implements IDungeonGenerator {
019
020    private IRNG rng;
021    private int width, height;
022    public char[][] dungeon;
023    
024    public GrowingTreeMazeGenerator(int width, int height) {
025        this.width = width;
026        this.height = height;
027        rng = new GWTRNG();
028    }
029    public GrowingTreeMazeGenerator(int width, int height, IRNG rng) {
030        this.width = width;
031        this.height = height;
032        this.rng = rng;
033    }
034
035    /**
036     * Gets the most recently-produced dungeon as a 2D char array, usually produced by calling {@link #generate()} or
037     * some similar method present in a specific implementation. This normally passes a direct reference and not a copy,
038     * so you can normally modify the returned array to propagate changes back into this IDungeonGenerator.
039     *
040     * @return the most recently-produced dungeon/map as a 2D char array
041     */
042    @Override
043    public char[][] getDungeon() {
044        return dungeon;
045    }
046
047    /**
048     * Builds and returns a 2D char array maze by using {@link #newest} with {@link #generate(ChoosingMethod)}.
049     * 
050     * @return {@link #dungeon}, after filling it with a maze
051     */
052    @Override
053    public char[][] generate() {
054        return generate(newest);
055    }
056
057    /**
058     * Builds and returns a 2D char array maze using the provided chooser method object. The most maze-like dungeons
059     * use {@link #newest}, the least maze-like use {@link #oldest}, and the most jumbled use {@link #random} or a
060     * mix of others using {@link #mix(ChoosingMethod, double, ChoosingMethod, double)}.
061     * 
062     * @param choosing the callback object for making the split decision
063     * @return {@link #dungeon}, after filling it with a maze
064     */
065    public char[][] generate(ChoosingMethod choosing) {
066        if(dungeon == null || dungeon.length != width || dungeon[0].length != height)
067            dungeon = ArrayTools.fill('#', width, height);
068        else 
069            ArrayTools.fill(dungeon, '#');
070        
071        int x = rng.between(1, width / 2);
072        int y = rng.between(1, height / 2);
073        x *= 2;
074        y *= 2;
075
076        OrderedSet<Coord> deck = new OrderedSet<>();
077        deck.add(Coord.get(x, y));
078
079        Direction[] dirs = new Direction[4];
080        System.arraycopy(Direction.CARDINALS, 0, dirs, 0, 4);
081        OUTER:
082        while (!deck.isEmpty()) {
083            int i = choosing.chooseIndex(deck.size());
084            Coord p = deck.getAt(i);
085            rng.shuffleInPlace(dirs);
086
087            for (Direction dir : dirs) {
088                x = p.x + dir.deltaX * 2;
089                y = p.y + dir.deltaY * 2;
090                if (x > 0 && x < width - 1 && y > 0 && y < height - 1) {
091                    if (dungeon[x][y] == '#' && deck.add(Coord.get(x, y))) {
092                        dungeon[x][y] = '.';
093                        dungeon[p.x + dir.deltaX][p.y + dir.deltaY] = '.';
094                        continue OUTER;
095                    }
096                }
097            }
098            
099            deck.remove(p);
100        }
101
102        return dungeon;
103    }
104
105    /**
106     * A way to configure how {@link #generate(ChoosingMethod)} places paths through the maze. Most often, you'll want
107     * to at least start with {@link #newest}, since it generates the most maze-like dungeons, and try the other
108     * predefined ChoosingMethods eventually. You can use {@link #mix(ChoosingMethod, double, ChoosingMethod, double)}
109     * to mix two ChoosingMethods, which can be a good way to add a little variety to a maze.
110     */
111    public interface ChoosingMethod {
112
113        /**
114         * Given the size to choose from, will return a single value smaller than the passed in value and greater than
115         * or equal to 0. The value chosen is dependent on the individual implementation.
116         *
117         * @param size the exclusive upper bound for results; always at least 1
118         * @return an int between 0 (inclusive) and {@code size} (exclusive)
119         */
120        int chooseIndex(int size);
121    }
122
123    /**
124     * Produces high-quality mazes that are very similar to those produced by a recursive back-tracking algorithm.
125     */
126    public final ChoosingMethod newest = new ChoosingMethod() {
127        @Override
128        public int chooseIndex(int size) {
129            return size - 1;
130        }
131    };
132    /**
133     * Produces mostly straight corridors that dead-end at the map's edge; probably only useful with {@link #mix(ChoosingMethod, double, ChoosingMethod, double)}.
134     */
135    public final ChoosingMethod oldest = new ChoosingMethod() {
136        @Override
137        public int chooseIndex(int size) {
138            return 0;
139        }
140    };
141    /**
142     * Produces chaotic, jumbled spans of corridors that are similar to those produced by Prim's algorithm.
143     */
144    public final ChoosingMethod random = new ChoosingMethod() {
145        @Override
146        public int chooseIndex(int size) {
147            return rng.nextSignedInt(size);
148        }
149    };
150
151    /**
152     * Mixes two ChoosingMethod values, like {@link #newest} and {@link #random}, given a weight for each, and produces
153     * a new ChoosingMethod that randomly (respecting weight) picks one of those ChoosingMethods each time it is used.
154     * @param methodA the first ChoosingMethod to mix; must not be null
155     * @param chanceA the weight to favor choosing methodA
156     * @param methodB the second ChoosingMethod to mix; must not be null
157     * @param chanceB the weight to favor choosing methodB
158     * @return a ChoosingMethod that randomly picks between {@code methodA} and {@code methodB} each time it is used
159     */
160    public ChoosingMethod mix(final ChoosingMethod methodA, final double chanceA,
161                              final ChoosingMethod methodB, final double chanceB) {
162        final double a = Math.max(0.0, chanceA);
163        final double sum = a + Math.max(0.0, chanceB);
164        if(sum <= 0.0) return random;
165        return new ChoosingMethod() {
166            @Override
167            public int chooseIndex(int size) {
168                return rng.nextDouble(sum) < a ? methodA.chooseIndex(size) : methodB.chooseIndex(size);
169            }
170        };
171    }
172}
